name: Bladder
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The urinary bladder is a distensible muscular sac. It is lined by urothelium which allows for significant stretching.

features: Muscularis propria: 3 layers of smooth muscle (Detrusor muscle)
theory.examTips: Look for Umbrella Cells: Large, binucleated, plaque-bearing cells on the surface. Epithelium thickness varies: 3-4 layers (distended) vs 6-7 layers (relaxed). No muscularis mucosae/submucosa distinct border.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Kidney
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The kidney consists of a cortex (containing glomeruli and convoluted tubules) and a medulla (containing loops of Henle and collecting ducts).

features: PCT (brush border, eosinophilic) & DCT (clearer lumen, no brush border)
Medulla: Collecting ducts (cuboidal/columnar) and Loops of Henle (squamous/cuboidal)
theory.examTips: Differentiate PCT vs DCT: PCT has messy lumen (brush border) and is very pink. DCT has clean lumen and is paler. Glomerulus = Ball of capillaries surrounded by Bowman's space.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Prostate
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The prostate is a fibromuscular glandular organ. It consists of tubuloalveolar glands embedded in a fibromuscular stroma.

features: Stroma: Abundant smooth muscle and collagen (Fibromuscular)
Corpora Amylacea (Prostatic concretions): Lamellated pink bodies in lumen (age-related)
function: Secretes proteolytic enzymes (PSA) and acid phosphatase
theory.examTips: Key ID features: Corpora Amylacea (looks like cut tree trunks/onions) + Fibromuscular Stroma (pink muscle everywhere between glands). Glands have papillary infoldings but NO true villi.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Seminal vesicle
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The seminal vesicles are paired glands composed of a highly coiled tube. The mucosa shows extensive branching and folding.

features: Extremely complex, honeycomb-like mucosal folds (Primary, Secondary, Tertiary folds)
theory.examTips: Honeycomb mucosa is the key. Often confused with Fallopian tube, but SV folds are finer, mesh-like/honeycombed, and the epithelium may contain golden brown pigment (lipofuscin). Fallopian tube has distinct finger-like plicae.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Epididymis
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The epididymis is a highly coiled tube connecting the testis to the vas deferens. It is the site of sperm maturation and storage.

features: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with Stereocilia (long microvilli)
theory.examTips: Stereocilia are NOT motile (they are actually microvilli). Look for 'clean' circular tubes filled with sperm clumps, lined by tall cells with 'not-cilia' (clumped stereocilia). Smooth muscle coat is circular.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Testis
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The testis is the male gonad, enclosed by the Tunica Albuginea. It consists of seminiferous tubules where spermatogenesis occurs.

features: Seminiferous Tubules: Complex stratified epithelium (Germinal epithelium)
Sertoli Cells (nurse cells): Pale, oval nucleus, support germ cells
Spermatogenic cells: Spermatogonia (basal), Spermatocytes, Spermatids, Spermatozoa (lumen)
Interstitial Cells of Leydig: Clusters in CT between tubules (secrete Testosterone)
theory.examTips: Identify Leydig cells (pink clusters in 'triangles' between round tubules). In tubules, Spermatogonia are on the BASEMENT MEMBRANE. Sperm tails in lumen. Sertoli cell nuclei are pale and large compared to dark round germ cells.

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System

name: Ureter
category: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
description: The ureter is a muscular tube transporting urine from kidney to bladder. It has a star-shaped lumen in cross-section.

features: Mucosa: Transitional epithelium (Urothelium) on lamina propria
Star-shaped lumen (due to longitudinal mucosal folds)
Muscularis: Inner longitudinal, Outer circular (Opposite of GI tract!)
Lower 1/3 has extra outer longitudinal layer
location: Extends from Renal Pelvis to Bladder
theory.examTips: Remember the muscle layers are OPPOSITE to the GIT. GIT = Inner Circular. Ureter = Inner Longitudinal. 'Lumen looks like a star'. Epithelium is transitional (dome cells).

path: Urogenital System and Male Reproductive System
